dialogues.text: What we need is a smoking role model. A real winner.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Indiana Jones meets Jerry Maguire...

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: on two packs a day.

dialogues.text: But he can’t live in contemporary society.  47.

dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Health issue is too prevalent. People will constantly ask why the character is smoking, when it should go unsaid. What do you think about the future?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: The future?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yes. After the health thing has blown over. A world where smokers and non- smokers live in perfect harmony. Sony has a futuristic sci-fi picture coming up. “Message from Sector Six”. It all takes place on a space station. They’re looking hard for any type of investor.

dialogues.text: Wouldn’t they blow up in an all oxygen environment.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Sector Sixes.

dialogues.text: No one’s done that with a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: NICK

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You go enjoy the rest of your day with your son in Los Angeles, while I find answers for our questions. EXT. L’ERMITAGE HOTEL - DAY A BELLMAN approaches Jack’s BMW and opens both car doors Nick and Joey.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (from driver’s seat) Yo, Nick. Great job today. You need anything, just call me. I know how lonely a strange city can be...

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (shutting door) Thank you Jack.

dialogues.speaker: BELLMAN
dialogues.text: Welcome to L’Ermitage, Mr. Naylor. Your suite is ready.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Where can we grab a bite? Something really, Los Angeles?

dialogues.speaker: BELLMAN
dialogues.text: Well, there’s Spago, Mortons Matsuhisa...

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No, no, no. Where do the people go?  49. EXT. HENRY’S TACO STAND - DAY The corner set taco stand in Los Angeles. To not know it to not have lived. Nick and Joey grabs their BURRITOS and COKES and have a s

dialogues.text: You go to an office. Then you go on TV and talk about cigarettes. Then you fly out to LA to talk to some guy who works with movie stars. What is that?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It’s my job. I’m a lobbyist.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: I know, but did you study to do that?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No, I just kind of figured it out.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Then, can’t anyone just do that?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No, I think it requires a moral flexibility that kind of goes beyond most people.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Do I have flexible morals?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Well, lets say you became a lawyer, right? And, you were asked to defend a murderer. Worse than that, a child murderer. The law states that every person deserves a fair trial. Would you defend him?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I guess every person deserves a fair defense.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yeah, well... So do multi-national corporations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mix of LA youth and family sift each way down the pier Nick and Joey lean on the rail, lost in conversation.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: So, what happens when you’re wrong?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No, Joey. I’m never wrong.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: You can’t always be right... Right?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: If it’s your job to be right. Then, you’re never wrong.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (still confused) But, what if you are wrong?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Okay, lets say you’re defending chocolate and I’m defending vanilla. Now, if I were to say to you, vanilla is the best flavor of ice cream, you'd Say...

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: No, chocolate is.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Exactly. But you can’t win that argument. So, I’ll ask you: So you think chocolate is the end all and be all of ice cream, do you?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (pushing adamance) It’s the best ice cream. I wouldn’t order any other.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Oh, so it’s all chocolate for you, is it?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Yes, chocolate is all I need.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Well, I need more than chocolate. And for that matter, I need more than vanilla. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I believe we need freedom and choice when it comes to our ice cream and that, Joey Naylor. That is the definition of liberty.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: But that’s not what we’re talking about

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: That’s what I’m talking about.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: But you didn’t prove that vanilla was the best.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I didn’t have to. I proved that you’re wrong. And if you’re wrong, I’m right.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: But you still didn’t convince me.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I’m not after you. (pointing to the crowded pier) I’m after them. Joey is beginning to understand.

dialogues.text: (checking his watch) Hello? INTERCUT WITH: INT. JEFF MEGALL’S OFFICE - SAME  52. Jeff sits at his desk, now wearing a KIMONO. The city lig twinkle behind him.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Oh, hi Jeff. You’re still at the office?

dialogues.text: Do you know what time it is in Tokyo right now?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.text: Twenty five? Usually when I buy two of something, I get a discount. What’s the extra five for?

dialogues.text: Synergy. These are not dumb people. They got it right away. Pitt and Zeta-Jones lighting up after some cosmic fucking in the bubble suite is going to sell a lot of cigarettes.

dialogues.text: For this kind of money, my people will expect some very serious smoking. Can Brad Pitt blow smoke rings?

dialogues.text: I don’t have that information.

dialogues.text: Nick, you know who Lorne Lutch is?

dialogues.text: The money is for him. He has a ranch out there in California. I want you to bring it to him.

dialogues.text: Hey, kiddo. Look, I’ve got to go and doa little more work this afternoon.

dialogues.text: (in shadows) You’re Nick Naylor, aren’t you?

dialogues.text: Do you... could I... do you have a minute?  56. Lorne emerges from the shadows, shotgun over his shoulder He’s broad and weathered. A cowboy with lung cancer.

dialogues.text: Dad...

dialogues.text: Mister, you’ve got a lot’a’nerve...

dialogues.text: Saw you on... weren’t you on that Oprah show?

dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.text: You’re lucky you made it out of there alive.

dialogues.text: Tobacco used to be all over television. Now, TV is leading the witch hunt.

dialogues.text: Strange business. In the early fifties they had the first cancer scare, so they brought in those filters. Then they got worried that men would think filters were for pussies. That’s where I came in.

dialogues.text: You were great. I used to want to be you. I mean, when I was growing up. We all did.

dialogues.text: Last year, after I got diagnosed, I flew east to attend the annual stockholders’ meeting. I stood up and told them that they ought to limit their advertising. And do you know what your boss said to me? Nick knows, but doesn’t interrupt.

dialogues.text: He said ‘We’re certainly sorry to hear about your medical problem. (MORE)

dialogues.text: Your dad always bring you along like this?

dialogues.text: You look like a nice enough fellah. what are you doing working for these assholes? Hold on Nick as he chooses his words carefully.  59.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I’m good at it. I’m better at doing this than I ever was at doing anything else.

dialogues.speaker: LORNE LUTCH
dialogues.text: Well hell, son, I was good at shooting Koreans, but I didn’t make it my career. There is a pause as Lorne studies Nick.

dialogues.speaker: LORNE LUTCH
dialogues.text: I suppose we all got to pay the mortgage somehow. Nick exhales.

dialogues.speaker: LORNE LUTCH
dialogues.text: So, you here to talk me into shutting up? Is that what’s in that case of yours? Joey stares, trying to keep up with the action.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yeah, basically... (picking up the briefcase) No, not basically. That’s exactly it.

dialogues.speaker: LORNE LUTCH
dialogues.text: My dignity ain’t for sale.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: This isn’t an offer. It’s a gift. The taxes have all been paid. You get to keep it no matter what you do. The idea is that your guilt will prevent you from bad- mouthing us.

dialogues.speaker: LORNE LUTCH
dialogues.text: Were you supposed to tell me all that?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No. Just apologize, give you the money, and leave.

dialogues.speaker: LORNE LUTCH
dialogues.text: Then why are you telling me this? A moment. Joey gets closer. Then... Nick ignites. He looks up at Lorne.  60.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Because this way, you’1ll take the money.

dialogues.text: Why would I do that?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Because you’re mad. The first thing you’1l do is call the LA Times and CNN.

dialogues.speaker: LORNE LUTCH
dialogues.text: Damn straight.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: And insist on Bonnie Dalton. She does really good controlled outrage. Tell them no Bonnie, no story, watch it on MSNBC.

dialogues.speaker: LORNE LUTCH
dialogues.text: (trying to keep up) Okay...

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: When they get here, open up the case and dump all the cash out onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: LORNE LUTCH

dialogues.text: The Sun bursts out from behind various monuments.  102.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a limo window, we see the press quickly approaching, all we hear is the sound of an on-coming wave. As the pre hits the car, the wave sound crashes as if hitting a beac Inside the car are a very shocked Nick, Bobby Jay, and Po

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JAY
dialogues.text: Still feel like Jimmy Stewart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MOD Squad fighting the on coming press as they approa the main entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick and Polly walk through the metal detector. Bobby Jay tries to walk through, but sets off the machine.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JAY
dialogues.text: (to Nick and Polly) Go ahead. This may take a while. A SECURITY GUARD approaches with the WAND. Bobby Jay has nothing but disdain for metal detectors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A A/V OPERATOR plugs in a mic sitting on the RED TABLECLO on the witnesses table. He gives a thumbs across the room where... A/V OPERATOR 2 turns on the P.A. system. The roo comes alive with a BOOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hearing is just beginning. Senator Finistirre and nin his colleagues sit at a long table before the audience. E one has a pitcher of water and a microphone. Finistirre s the audience, then begins.

dialogues.speaker: FINISTIRRE
dialogues.text: Okay, lets bring this meeting to order. We’ll try our best to keep everything brief and concise, so we can all make it out of here on time. Finistirre smiles at his audience.  103.

dialogues.speaker: FINISTIRRE
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MEDICAL ADVISOR is testifying.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL ADVISOR
dialogues.text: The skull and crossbones means one thing: Poison. Thus, the message is quite clear Like any other product that carries the branding, if you take it, you will die.

dialogues.speaker: FINISTIRRE
dialogues.text: Is this not overkill? I mean, why not just use words as we currently do? Something that describes the dangers of cigarettes?

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL ADVISOR
dialogues.text: The American public is not affected by mast head anymore. They need photographs. We’ve done studies which show that consumers react up to eighty percent more to imagery rather than words. The stats are there. It’s just sad that the Academy of Tobacco Studies did not release this type of information earlier...

dialogues.speaker: FINISTIRRE
dialogues.text: And when you say the Academy of Tobacco Studies, you are referring to the coalition represented by... FREEZE FRAME on the Senator.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Let it be known, the public beating has not gone out of style.

dialogues.speaker: LATINO MAN
dialogues.text: The current use of words instead of imagery is an obvious move against the non-English speaking population in the United States. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: LATINO MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The skull and crossbones speaks loudly in all languages. By not using it, they are saying they want those who can’t read English to die.

dialogues.speaker: FINISTIRRE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry Senor Herera, could you please clarify “they”...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finistirre looks down at his agenda and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: FINISTIRRE
dialogues.text: Nick Naylor, please step forward. Nick stands. He turns around as he fixes his suit coat. A does, he notices someone in the audience. Sitting ten row back is... Joey. The twelve year old sneaks an excited wa Nick suddenly becomes uncomfortable. He waves back, but w can tell he is bothered.

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: Please state your name, address, and current occupation.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: My name is Nick Naylor. I live at the Watergate. I am currently unemployed, but until recently, I was the Vice President of the Academy of Tobacco Studies.

dialogues.speaker: FINISTIRRE
dialogues.text: Mr. Naylor, as Vice President of the Academy of Tobacco Studies, what was required of you? What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I informed the public of all the research performed in the investigation on the effects of tobacco.

dialogues.speaker: FINISTIRRE
dialogues.text: And what, so far, has the Academy concluded in the investigation on the effects of tobacco?  105.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Well, many things actually. Why just the other day, they uncovered evidence that smoking can offset Parkinson's disease.

dialogues.speaker: FINISTIRRE
dialogues.text: I’m sure the health community is thrilled. Mr. Naylor, Who provides the financial backing for the Academy of Tobacco Studies?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Conglomerated Tobacco.

dialogues.speaker: FINISTIRRE
dialogues.text: (clarifying) That is the cigarette companies?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: For the most part, yes.

dialogues.speaker: FINISTIRRE
dialogues.text: Do you think this affects their priorities?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No. Just as I’m sure campaign contributions don’t affect yours. Senator LOTHRIDGE from Washington pipes in, to break it u

dialogues.speaker: LOTHRIDGE
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, Mr. Naylor is not here to testify on the goings on of the Academy of Tobacco Studies. We’re here to examine the possibility of a warning logo on cigarettes. Now, Mr. Naylor, I have to ask out of formality, do you believe that smoking cigarettes over time can lead to lung cancer and other respiratory conditions such as emphysema? Finistirre rolls his eyes. (What do you think?) A long pause, as Nick searches through everything. The pe in this room. The people watching on television. The peop watching down from heaven.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yes.  106. Finistirre looks up in astonishment as the whole room sud bustles with energy. Polly and Bobby Jay exchange glances

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: In fact, I think you’d be hard pressed to find someone who really believes that cigarettes are not potentially harmful. (turns to audience) I mean, show of hands...

dialogues.speaker: LOTHRIDGE
dialogues.text: Mr. Naylor, there is no need for theatrics.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I just don’t see the point in a warning label for something people already know. Senator DUPREE from Michigan joins in.

dialogues.speaker: DUPREE
dialogues.text: The warning symbol is a reminder of the dangers of smoking cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Well, if we want to remind people of danger, why don’t we slap a skull and crossbones on all Boeing Airplanes, Senator Lothridge... We notice for the first time, Lothridge’s name plate says WASHINGTON.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: and all Fords, Senator Dupree. Dupree’s name plate says (R) MICHIGAN.

dialogues.speaker: FINISTIRRE
dialogues.text: That’s just ridiculous. The death toll on passenger planes and car fatalities doesn’t even skim the surface of cigarettes. They don’t even compare.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Oh, this from a Senator who calls Vermont, home. Finistirre raises an eyebrow.  107.

dialogues.speaker: LOTHRIDGE
dialogues.text: I don’t follow, Mr. Naylor.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Well the real demonstrated number-one killer in America is cholesterol. Still stares. Nick continues.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: And here comes Senator Finistirre, whose fine state is, I regret to say, clogging the nation’s arteries with Vermont cheddar cheese. If you want to talk numbers, how about the millions of people dying of heart attacks. Perhaps Vermont cheddar should come with a skull and crossbones.

dialogues.speaker: FINISTIRRE
dialogues.text: You little... Lothridge covers Finistirre’s mic so we don’t hear the wo “shit”. Finistirre is fuming. Lothridge cools him down. Nick looks back at Joey who gives him the thumbs up.

dialogues.speaker: LOTHRIDGE
dialogues.text: Mr. Naylor, we are here to discuss cigarettes. Not any other products. Now, as discussed earlier, these warning labels are not for those who know, but rather for those who don’t. What about the children?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, it’s called education. It doesn’t come off the side of a cigarette carton. It comes from our teachers and more importantly our parents. It is every parents’ job to warn their children of all the dangers of the world, including cigarettes. So one day, when they get older, they can make an educated choice. Not to be corny, but that is what this country is supposed to be all about. Some say it takes a village to raise a child. I disagree. It takes two parents. And sometimes, just one. Nick looks back at his son.  108.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I look at my son today, and I can’t help think of myself as responsible for his growth and his development. And I’m proud of that.

dialogues.speaker: FINISTIRRE
dialogues.text: In that case, Mr. Naylor, would you condone him smoking?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Of course not, he’s not eighteen. That would be illegal.

dialogues.speaker: FINISTIRRE
dialogues.text: Yes, I heard you deliver the same response on 20/20. But enough dancing. What about when he does turn eighteen? Nick is momentarily speechless.

dialogues.speaker: FINISTIRRE
dialogues.text: Come on Mr. Naylor? On your son’s eighteenth birthday, will you share a cigarette? Enjoy the afternoon like one of those sick tobacco advertisements? You certainly have a lot to say on how we should raise our children. What of your own? What will you do when he turns eighteen? Joey looks to his father. Nick looks up at the various senators. He takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: If he really wants a cigarette... I’1l buy him his first pack. Joey smiles proudly. Finistirre rocks back.

dialogues.speaker: FINISTIRRE
dialogues.text: Thank you for your testimony, Mr. Naylor. Nick nods and stand up to leave. As he does, many of the spectators stand to leave with him out into the...  109.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick, now surrounded by REPORTERS, PHOTOGRAPHERS, ADMIRER and DETRACTORS, tries to make his way outside. Somehow, t crowd separates momentarily and BR squeezes in next to Ni

dialogues.speaker: BR
dialogues.text: Well done, my boy! Nick looks over, confused. My boy?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Were you in the same room as me?

dialogues.speaker: BR
dialogues.text: The whole personal choice thing. They ate up that shit. We checked the whip count The bill is going down in flames. Your speech was... unorthodox, but you did it... You crushed the fucker.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: That’s great news for you guys.

dialogues.speaker: BR
dialogues.text: Hey, now. We’re still a team, right?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What about, “damage control”? Nick and BR stop at the MAIN DOORS. The crowd still surrounding them.

dialogues.speaker: BR
dialogues.text: (levels with him) Look, Nick. Winston-Salem is ready to do whatever it takes to keep you on board... Nick thinks for a moment, then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick and his son Joey stand on the main steps, surrounded reporters. Joey looks to his dad with pride.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 1
dialogues.text: Nick, will you continue to fight for cigarettes? BR enters and puts his arm around Nick.  110.

dialogues.speaker: BR
dialogues.text: Of course he will! This man here is our general. We’re not going to just let him retire.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 2
dialogues.text: Is that correct, Nick? You’re sticking with tobacco?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (smiles, then...) Smoking is a personal freedom that is enjoyed by countless Americans, and although I cannot smoke anymore due to my injurious kidnapping, I believe in protecting all freedoms... Meanwhile, as Nick continues, we take a look at JOEY. He’ proud of his dad. So proud, that he opens a pack of MARLB REDS and pulls out a cigarette. He takes it between his fingers and raises it to his twelve year old LIPS. Out of the corner of Nick’s eye, he sees his son about to onto a cigarette. And before Nick can stop himself, his a whips down and SLAPS the cigarette out of his son’s mouth We see this repeat through the eyes of the cameras:

dialogues.speaker: CBS
dialogues.text: The cigarette flies through the air in super Slo-Mo as: Camera men smile. Videotape rolls. A SATELLITE circles the Earth. Controllers in a TV STUDIO switch to camera A. Multiple TELEVISIONS broadcast the event in a window of a electronics shop in Tokyo. And of course... BR’s eyes bulge in horror.  111.

dialogues.speaker: AND THEN
dialogues.text: The cigarette hits the ground. Nothing big. Just drops. P.O.V. - One of the TV cameras. Slightly shaky close-up o cigarette sitting on the Capital Steps. It looks pathetic

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: My father gave me one word of advice before he died: Prioritize. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So, what happens to a guy a like me? I know what you’re probably thinking... Close of a PAIR OF LOAFERS standing on the ledge of a skyscraper. One foot steps out over the edge, then FREEZE

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: No, nothing like that. In fact, not much has changed.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The MOD squad still meets every week. We find Nick, Bobby Jay, and Polly sitting in the stands. Joey catches a long fly ball in right field. The MOD squa screams in celebration as Joey’s team runs to the dugout.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Senator Finistirre is still fighting for his causes. Finistirre is interviewed by a plastic HOLLYWOOD INTERVIE

dialogues.speaker: FINISTIRRE
dialogues.text: Movies are ruining our children. Every time they see an actor engaging in violence, casual sex, or smoking, they lose a year on their childhood.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: What’s you favorite movie?  112.

dialogues.speaker: FINISTIRRE
dialogues.text: Well you can’t mess with a classic. I love West Side Story.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: Doesn’t that have violence, casual sex, and smoking? Finistirre fumes.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Even Heather is still reporting. Heather and a CAMERA MAN for some expose show stand outsi New York BROWNSTONE. Sean Penn steps out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Sean, is it true...? Penn punches her in the face, leveling her to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick is lost in his thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Not much changes at all.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: Nick, Bobby Jay has some big news.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You were able to knock the spotted owl off of the endangered species list?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JAY
dialogues.text: (complete sincerity) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Wow, I can finally go kill myself a spotted owl.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JAY
dialogues.text: You could kill ten spotted owls. The MOD squad clink their plastic coke cups in celebratio  113.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Nothing changes at all. Even at my new job...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick faces three GENTLEMEN in nice suits.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: So, be straight with me. Is it true? Obvious embarrassment and confusion around the table.

dialogues.speaker: GENTLEMEN 1
dialogues.text: It could be.

dialogues.speaker: GENTLEMEN 2
dialogues.text: Well, we don’t quite know that. It’s complicated.

dialogues.speaker: GENTLEMEN 3
dialogues.text: Very few cases, really.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Look, gentlemen. Practice these words in front of a mirror: ‘Although we are constantly exploring the subject, currently, there is no direct evidence that links cell phone usage to brain cancer.’ The gentlemen smile to each other. They’ve found their ma Push into Nick. He looks straight at camera and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Michael Jordan plays ball. Charles Manson kills people. I talk.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Everyone has a talent.
